Blunder, Rc1 has the Rook defended by the Bishop on f4 but is also a blunder, best move with this Rook would be Rd1 to guard against ... Qc3+ with Bd2.
Because he did not play Rd1, Bd2 would just force mate in two with ... Qxd2+ Kf1 Qxf2#.
Because he did not play Rd1, Bd2 would just force mate in two with ... Qxd2+ Kf1 Qxf2#.
Kg1 a better move here, even though mate has been forced since Rb1.  Instead, mate is now in 5 rather than around 8.  I used this position for chess puzzle #47830.
Kg1 a better move here, even though mate has been forced since Rb1.  Instead, mate is now in 5 rather than around 8.  I used this position for chess puzzle #47830.
The key move here in this mate, with the Rook being protected by the c5 Bishop.
Kg1 would still result in mate with ... Qxb1+ Bc1 Qxc1+ Qd1 Qxd1#.
Potentially I could have played ... Qxe4+ here as well, either resulting in Qg2 Qxg2# or Qf3 Qxf3+ Kg1 Qg2#, or if Kg1 then ... Qxb1+ Bc1 Qxc1+ Qd1 Qxd1#.
White could've lengthened the game with Bc1 before this move, preventing ... Qxe4+, but instead would've resulted in ... Qxh6+ Qh2, then either Rxh2# or Qxh2#.
Now his only move is Qg2.
And checkmate.
And checkmate.
